questions.question: Which of the following is not a property of fibers in the dorsal column pathway?
questions.explanation: The dorsal column-medial lemniscal system is composed of large, myelinated nerve fibers andthus transmit signals to the brain, at high velocities of 30 to 110 m/sec.Option B: Dorsal column carries fine touch and anterolateral column carries crude touch233

questions.question: A patient comes to you for his annual health checkup. He lost his vision due to an accident afew years ago. He now experiences the world through touch. Which of the followingBrodmann's areas processes this tactile stimulation?
questions.explanation: Processing of tactile stimulation occurs in Brodmann's area in 3, 1, 2.The human cerebral cortex is divided into about 50 distinct areas called Brodmann's areas basedon histological structural differences.Areas 3, 1, 2 which constitute primary somatosensory area I, and areas 5 and 7, which constitutethe somatosensory association area process sensory information like tactile stimulation.

questions.question: Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is
questions.explanation: Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is vertical.Parts of the body are represented in order along the postcentral gyrus, with the legs on top andhead at the bottom of the gyrus.A cortical homunculus is a distorted representation of the human body, based on a neurologicalmap of the areas and proportions of the human brain dedicated to processing motor functions, orsensory functions, for different parts of the body. The size of the cortical receiving area forimpulses from a particular part of the body is proportionate to the use of the part.Sensory Homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of sensory input to thesomatosensory cortex from different parts of the body.Motor homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of motor output from primarymotor cortex to different parts of the body.Sensory homunculus is depicted below:HipLegFootToesGenitalsMOOISWristHandLittleRingMiddleIndexThumbEyeNoseFaceTeeth,gums,and jawLipsTonguePharynx234

questions.question: Somatosensory area has the largest representation for226

questions.question: A patient sustains an injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the righthemisphere. Loss of sensation is likely to be seen at which of the following sites in thispatient?

questions.question: Lesion of somatosensory area I affects
questions.explanation: Lesion of the somatosensory area I affects the localization of sensations.Bilateral lesion of the somatosensory area I leads to the following impairment of sensoryjudgment:••Inability to localize different sensations in different parts of the bodyInability to judge degrees of pressure against the bodyInability to judge the weight of the objects• Inability to judge shapes of forms of objects - astereognosis• Inability to judge the texture of the materialsPain and temperature are not affected both in quality and intensity in the lesion of thesomatosensory area I. However, they are poorly localised. Pain and temperature localizationdepends greatly on the topographical map of the body in somatosensory area I to localize thesource.

questions.question: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, acomplete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following islikely to be seen in this patient?

options.A: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
options.B: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
options.C: Pain and temperature lost on the same side
options.D: Only pain lost on the same side

questions.explanation: This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain andtemperature on the opposite side.Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway,ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which iscalled the Brown-Séquard syndrome.The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminativetouch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.236The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensationbeginning one or two segments below the lesion.Damage to the corticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups onthe same side of the body.

questions.question: 227Which of the following findings are seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?

options.A: Upper Motor Neuron type of paralysis below the lesion on the opposite side
options.B: Impaired fine touch below the lesion on the opposite side
options.C: Loss of crude touch below the lesion on the same side
options.D: Loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side

questions.explanation: A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have a loss of vibration sense below the lesion on thesame side.Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can be caused byfracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor.Clinical features:• Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) belowthe level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).• Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration belowthe level of lesion on the same side of lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla).Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the levelof the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline afterentering the cord).•

questions.question: Itch is carried by
questions.explanation: Itch-specific fibers have been demonstrated in the anterolateral spinothalamic tract. They arecarried by unmyelinated nerve fiber C. Itching can be produced by repeated local mechanicalstimulation of skin, variety of chemical agents including histamine and kinins released in the skinin response to tissue damageSimple scratching relieves itching because it activates large fast conducting afferents (Aẞ) that gatethe transmission in the dorsal horn in a manner analogous to inhibition of pain by stimulation ofsimilar afferents (Gate control theory).

questions.question: Following are the endogenous opioids except_
questions.explanation: Endogenous opioids, a group of neuropeptides that includesbeta-endorphin, dynorphins, and enkephalins.Opioids cause both presynaptic and post synaptic inhibition reducing excitatory post-synapticpotential (EPSP). Opioids are released from the descending analgesic pathway and bind withopiate receptors on the afferent pain-fiber terminal. This binding suppresses the release ofsubstance P, blocking further transmission of the pain signal.237

questions.question: You are examining a patient for a follow-up of severe pain in his right leg. He tells you that hefeels much better now that he is taking acupuncture therapy too. Which of the following isresponsible for pain relief in acupuncture?
questions.explanation: Pain relief in acupuncture is by the release of endorphin.The acupuncture endorphin hypothesis is the primary mechanism of acupuncture analgesia.According to this hypothesis, Acupuncture is thought to activate afferent neurons leading to spinalcord and midbrain centers that release endogenous opioids implicated in pain relief.

questions.question: 228Fast pain is carried by
questions.explanation: Fast pain is carried by neospinothalamic tract.Pain signals take two pathways to the brain:• Neospinothalmic tract for fast pain/epicritic pain (AS fibres)• Paleospinothalamic tract for slow pain/Protopathic pain (C fibres)

questions.question: Soldiers wounded in the heat of battle often feel no pain until the battle is over which is anexample of stress-induced analgesia. This is due to
questions.explanation: Stress induced analgesia is due to cannabinoids.The stress-induced analgesia, i.e., reduced pain sensitivity during stressful events might be due to:• Release of endogenous cannabinoids such as 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG) and anandamide• Release of Norepinephrine from brainstem catecholaminergic neurons in the amygdala.

questions.question: 229Ventrolateral cordotomy for relief of pain in the right lower limb is being performed on apatient. Which of the following is cut in this procedure?
questions.explanation: In ventrolateral cordotomy, selected pain-conducting tracts in the spinal cord, i.e. fibers in thelateral spinothalamic pathway, are cut leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperaturesensation below the level of the lesion.In the more recent percutaneous approach, destruction of the lateral spinothalamic at the level ofC1-C2 results in a contralateral disruption of painful sensations beyond C4.Note: The fibers carrying pain sensation ascend in the lateral spinothalamic tract while the fiberscarrying crude touch and pressure sensations ascend in the anterior spinothalamic tract.

questions.question: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?

options.A: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
options.B: Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
options.C: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
options.D: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.explanation: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on theopposite side.Fibers of medial lemniscus ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns of the spinal cord to themedulla, where they synapse in the gracilus and cuneate nuclei.The second-order neurons from these nuclei cross the midline and ascend in the medial lemniscusto end in the contralateral ventral posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus and related specific sensoryrelay nuclei of the thalamus.
